title: Ukiyo-e: Standing Courtesan
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Janice Katz.

Janice Katz: So in this gallery, which we’re calling “Early Ideals of Beauty,” is where we start to get
images of these bijin, these beauties, a singular beauty on each hanging scroll. In this painting, we see
one particularly high-ranking courtesan who is shown walking towards the right, gathering her heavy
robes up in one hand. Her outer robe, in particular, has this incredible lavish detail. Several patterns are
going on, of chrysanthemums against the dark ground as well as mulberry leaves against the gray
ground. The dark ground that is around the chrysanthemums was originally silver. It’s a silver pigment
that has oxidized and turned darker over the years. The red robe that she wears under her outer robe is
painted with these interesting lines, short lines, throughout, probably to indicate some kind of heavy
fabric, tufted fabric like a velvet of some sort.

Janice Katz: So red is a color that one often finds on the inside inner robes, and it really sets off the
paleness of her skin and the scene, in many ways, as something that is erotic. I mean, red is the color. If
a kimono had red in it, it was considered colorful; if it did not have red, even if it had other colors, it was
considered not colorful.
